Description.val:
The Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW) mission package enables the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) to conduct detect-to-engage operations against modern submarines that pose a threat. Specific ASW capabilities include protecting forces in transit, protecting joint operating areas, and establishing ASW barriers. The ASW MP is developed to provide the warfighter capabilities that can be employed for ASW area search as well as high value unit escort missions and composed of an Escort Mission Module (EMM), a Torpedo Defense Module (TDM), and an Aviation Module.  The EMM components include a Variable Depth Sonar (VDS), a Multi-Function Towed Array (MFTA), associated winch and handling equipment, and a MPCE Sonar Signal Processing suite. The Torpedo Defense Module utilizes the Light Weight Tow Torpedo countermeasures system, associated winch and handling equipment, and a control station. The Aviation Module provides airborne threat localization and engagement capability through an MH-60R helicopter with MK54 torpedoes and sonobuoys, as well as associated storing and handling gear. The ability to incorporate a Fire Scout Vertical Takeoff and Landing Unmanned Aerial Vehicle is an additional capability within the Aviation Module.

An ASW Mission Package is deployable and capable of meeting its focused mission requirements on an LCS only when it includes the full complement of Common Mission Modules Equipment (Line Item Number 1600) and the full complement of mission systems that comprise the LCS ASW Mission Module (Line Item Number 1602). If mission systems are removed from the mission module in any given Fiscal Year, the ASW Mission Package will be non-deployable until the mission system is replaced in a subsequent Fiscal Year.

The number of LCS mission packages must not only keep pace with the number of ships, more are required to account for the mission packages that will be forward staged or unavailable due to periodic maintenance requirements.

Other Related Budgets: BLIs: OPN 1600, OPN 1601, OPN 1603, RDT&E 0603596N

[P5 / (AS001) - ASW Escort Module]: The ASW Escort Mission Module (MM) contains the sensors and signal processing required to detect, classify and localize submarine threats.  The Escort MM consists of two towed sensors; a VDS active source and an MFTA passive/bi-static active receiver; launch, handling and recovery equipment for the towed sensors, and AN/SQQ-89 V(15) active and passive signal processing applications.

[P5 / (AS002) - Torpedo Defense Countermeasure Module]: The Light Weight Tow (LWT) system is a towed persistent torpedo countermeasure optimized for use in littoral conditions.  LWT is a standalone autonomous system capable of defeating threat torpedoes through soft-kill to independently increase LCS Platform Probability of Survival.

[P5 / (AS005) - ASW Mission Package Containers]: The foundation of each ASW Support Container (SC) is an International Organization for Standardization (ISO) compliant shipping container. The ISO shipping containers are outfitted with Unistrut rails (for shelving and drawer attachments), lighting (standard/emergency), fire/smoke alarms, service panels for power, and a circuit breaker box. From this base container configuration, a variety of racks, cradles, and handling gear can be installed as needed to form a SC.

[P5 / (AS900) - Consulting Services]: Provides program management support, engineering and technical support, studies, analysis and evaluation on mission module systems.

Justification.val:
FY 2019 funding includes the procurement of two ASW Mission Packages, as well as associated support costs.  

In FY17, the Navy awarded a contract to Raytheon Corporation, Portsmouth, RI, to build the ASW EMM. Raytheon is developing the initial EMM Pre-Production Test Article (PPTA) that will undergo acoustic characterization end-to-end integration testing and two phases of dockside testing in 3Q FY 2018 and 4Q FY 2018.   Raytheon is on track to deliver the initial EMM PPTA in Q1 FY 2019.  Following delivery, white ship testing is planned for 2Q FY 2019 to characterize hydrodynamic performance.  LCS ship modification planning and design efforts are proceeding as planned in FY 2018, leading to modifications to USS Fort Worth (LCS 3) that will allow embarkation of the ASW MP in early FY 2019 for formal testing.  Contractor testing and two phases of formal developmental testing (including DOE runs) of the EMM on the Freedom variant will support the production decision in Q3FY19.  In addition, the EMM TDP will be validated, a PCA will be completed, manufacturing procedures will be developed, manufacturing material and tooling will be procured, a PRR will be completed, and integration efforts will be underway on the Independence variant prior to the production decision.

Name.@footnote: In FY19 the Production Readiness/Production NRE will ensure smooth and timely transition from development of the Pre-Production Test Article (PPTA) to the production of LRIP units.  NRE efforts include, transition the PPTA TDP to manufacturing drawings, completion of validation/verification procedures, procurement of manufacturing materials and tooling - to start up the production line. The NRE is a contractual requirement.

Model.val: ASW Mission Package Light Weight Tow

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: ASW MP Kits

Description.val:
For LCS Freedom variant, seaframe changes include installation of a fairlead and bellmouth thru the starboard transom, and a winch foundation.  For LCS Independence variant, seaframe changes include installation of a fairlead and bellmouth through the starboard amah, a winch foundation, and a sheave.

[ASW MP Kits] Funds the modifications to the current LCS designs to accommodate the ASW mission package configuration. All LCS ships will require the installation of the ASW Ship Alteration. 

ASW Ship alterations are funded in the year of installation(aka, year of need), not in the year of system/Module procurement
